awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Lignin derived bio-based materials and chemicals
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to enable the development of alternatives to petrochemicals can be economically produced. The core technology is a process for the conversion of lignin to value-added, sustainable chemical products with a focus on high-performance materials. The commercialization of this technology will potentially result in a significant reduction in the environmental impact of plastic production. The development will also unlock a new and sustainable revenue stream for the pulp & paper industry, enabling new organic growth as the paper market continues to shrink. Additionally, value-added products from lignin will potentially allow the biorefining industry to be cost-competitive with petrochemicals as the market for chemical alternatives grows.

This I-Corps project is centered around converting lignin, the structural component of woody biomass, into cost-competitive, value-added chemicals and materials via catalytic depolymerization. Lignin is currently considered a waste stream by the pulp & paper and biorefining industries, with more than 98% of the 70 million tons separated annually being burned for energy recovery. Other low-value uses for lignin include fillers for concrete, asphalt, and tire rubber, and moderate-value applications include polymer composites and chemicals from pyrolysis. The depolymerization technology at the core of this proposal breaks down lignin to yield platform chemicals, with the key advantage over other technologies being the product selectivity. The chemical products have wide-ranging applications in adhesives, coatings, and many other polymers applications and are often performance-advantaged with respect to thermal and mechanical properties and other materials characteristics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The Lignolix team has developed a technology to selectively deconstruct lignin, a major component of woody biomass, into its chemical building blocks. These chemicals have utility in many applications, including flavors & fragrances, cosmetics, and polymers. The team conducted over 178 customer interviews over the course of the I-Corps Teams program to validate its product-market fit and better define its value propositions.

The primary beachhead market of interest was the cosmetic additives market – specifically preservatives – because it enables low-volume, high-value operations. After conducting numerous interviews in this space, the Lignolix team concluded that indie cosmetics brands were the target customer groups. Lignolix’s product could provide the most value to these customers because they often did not use any preservatives at all because no inexpensive, natural, and effective preservatives were available.

In the polymers space, Lignolix more quickly gained traction with potential customers, and these interviews led to long-term customer relationships that have generated significant revenue for the company. This space is the current focus for the Lignolix team, and product development is ongoing with continued customer engagement.

Since the I-Corps Teams program ended, the team has formed a company and also has had success in securing an exclusive license for the core invention from the University of Delaware. Furthermore, the team has moved to a larger space with improved scale-up capabilities and brought on both part-time and full-time employees. The company also has secured multiple state and federal grants for continued process development, R&D, and product development. The NSF I-Corps Teams program was an invaluable experience for Lignolix, and the findings from the customer discovery process have guided the team to gain real market traction. Going forward, Lignolix hopes to make a broader impact by bringing sustainable, bio-based materials to market and advancing the field of biorefining with scalable and efficient chemical processing approaches.


Last Modified: 03/03/2023
Modified by: Dan Freeman
